title: Swiss Inflation Holds Steady as SNB Mulls Rate Cut Below Zero
content:
Swiss annual inflation held at a low level in August, keeping the country's central bank on guard as it considers cutting its key interest rate to below zero later this month.

Consumer prices were 0.2% higher than the same month of last year, matching July's rate, Switzerland's statistics office said Thursday. That remains within the Swiss National Bank's target of positive inflation lower than 2%.

The SNB meets later in September, with most investors currently expecting it to hold its key rate at 0%. The central bank last cut its key rate in June as it sought to rein in appreciation of the Swiss franc, which had acted as a safe haven for investors amid the turmoil of increased trade tariffs and Middle East tensions. A higher franc makes exports more expensive for foreign importers. The dollar has lost around 10% against the franc in the last six months.

The bank at its last meeting in June forecast average annual inflation at 0.2% for 2025, before rising to 0.5% and 0.7% for 2026 and 2027, respectively, should interest rates be left at zero until then.
summary: Swiss annual inflation remained low in August, with consumer prices rising by 0.2% compared to the previous year. The Swiss National Bank (SNP) is considering reducing its key interest rate to below zero in an attempt to curb the appreciation of the Swiss franc. The bank forecasts average annual inflation of 0.5% for 2025 and 0.7% for 2026.
shortSummary: Swiss annual inflation remained low in August, with the SNB considering a potential interest rate cut below zero, amid concerns over a stronger franc.
argos_summary: Swiss inflation held steady at 0.2% in August, matching July, and remains within the SNB’s target of positive inflation below 2%. The SNB is considering cutting its key rate below zero later this month, with most investors expecting a 0% stance at the September meeting. The recent rate cut in June aimed to curb the Swiss franc’s appreciation, which has made Swiss exports more expensive amid trade tariff tensions and Middle East unrest. The SNB forecasts inflation to rise to 0.5% in 2026 and 0.7% in 2027 if rates stay at zero.
